qas.question: In what year was Brigham Young Academy split into two separate schools?
What was the name of the land purchased by BYU in 1904?
How old was George H. Brimhall when he completed High School?
What topic was excluded from being taught at BYU?
Who was chosen to head BYU?
In 1903, which two institutions was Brigham Young Univesity replaced with?

answers.text: Brigham Young High School, and Brigham Young University

qas.question: Who we responsible for the giant "Y" that is embedded on a mountain near the campus?
At what age did BYU's elected president in 1904, George H. Brimhall, receive his high school education?
What brief crisis rose in the school at the time of Brimhall's presidency that caused the crises' theory to not be taught for a time?
What property was George Brimhall responsible for purchasing for the campus?
What was George B. Hrimhall elected as?
What were the 96,000m2 of land purchased by BYU called?

plausible_answers.text: by asking that evolution not be taught at the school.

qas.question: How did Joseph F. Maeser solve the theory of evolution crisis?
Who was forty when he completed university?

context: In <a0_0>1903<a0_0/>, <b10_0>Brigham Young Academy<b10_0/> was dissolved, and was replaced by two institutions: <a5_0>Brigham Young High School, and Brigham Young University<a5_0/>. (The <a6_0>BY High School class of 1907<a6_0/> was ultimately responsible for the famous giant "Y" that is to this day embedded on a mountain near campus.) The Board elected <a4_0><b14_0>George H. Brimhall<b14_0/><a4_0/> as the <b11_0>new President of BYU<b11_0/>. He had not received a high school education until he was <a2_0><a7_0>forty<a7_0/><a2_0/>. Nevertheless, he was an excellent orator and organizer. Under his tenure in 1904 the new Brigham Young University bought 17 acres (69,000 m2) of land from Provo called <b12_0>"<a1_0><a9_0>Temple Hill<a9_0/><a1_0/>".<b12_0/> After some controversy among locals over BYU's purchase of this property, construction began in 1909 on the first building on the current campus, the Karl G. Maeser Memorial. Brimhall also presided over the University during a brief crisis involving <a8_0>the theory of evolution<a8_0/>. The religious nature of the school seemed at the time to collide with this scientific theory. Joseph F. Smith, LDS Church president, settled the question for a time <b13_0>by asking that <a3_0>evolution<a3_0/> not be taught at the school.<b13_0/> A few have described the school at this time as nothing more than a "religious seminary". However, many of its graduates at this time would go on to great success and become well renowned in their fields.
